div1.p: Hench questions Moran about the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Interview of John J. Moran by Philip Showalter Hench, April 3, 1940

head.hi: QUESTIONING OF Mr. MORAN BY Dr. HENCH, HAVANA, CUBA, APRIL 3, 1940.

list.item: Q. How was Dr. Reed's request made known to the soldiers.

A. Principally through the medium of Dr. Roger Post Ames, by word of mouth.
Within three days the news had spread throughout the camp.
Q. When did Dr. Ames mention it to you.

A. It was between October 31st and November 5th. The exact month and date
would not be remembered by me since I did not consider them of such far-
reaching importance.
Q. Did you broach the news to Kissinger and did he know about it before you did.

A. I broke the news to him and according to my absolute knowledge he did not
know anything about it previously. Dr. Ames broke the news to me about
4:30 in the afternoon. Kissinger and I roomed together and that same
evening evening I told Kissinger of Dr. Ames' conversation with me and we
discussed it, as nearly as I can remember, until 2 o'clock in the morning.
Q. Do you remember anything you said to each other.

A. I remember distinctly that after Kissinger had informed me of his determin-
ation to volunteer for the experiments I said to him: “John, I am going into
these experiments as a fitting start in medicine, so please think very care-
fully of what you propose to do because, after all, we have no certainty
that we will survive the experiments,” or words to that effect. He answered
me back in the same way. “John, (I was John to him also) whatever you do I
am going to do. I am going with you”. We started talking about it at
9 o'clock and discussed it until at least 2 o'clock in the morning, cover-
ing all phases and angles of the problem.
Q. Did Kissinger make up his mind to volunteer before you talked with him.
A. Positively not. He knew nothing about it.

Q. Did Kissinger ever mention to you that he had volunteered and that he had
already been bitten by a mosquito.
A. No. The two preceding questions answer that.

Q. What was the attitude of the men around the camp and the doctors toward
the mosquito theory at that time.

A. That is a question I cannot answer except in a general way. The only
doctor I discussed it with was Dr. Ames. He did not give an opinion. He
approached me, knowing that I intended to enter the University of Virginia
in September of the coming year to study medicine. He called me “Johnny”
as I knew him well. He said: “This is a golden opportunity for you to add
to your slender educational fund.”
Q. He did not warn you about the danger.
A. No.

Q. If Dr. Ames did not warn you of the danger, presumably he did not think
much of the idea himself.

A. It was not part of Dr. Ames' mission to warn us. His mission was to quietly
let it be known that Major Reed was seeking volunteers.

Q. You went to bed for a few hours sleep. Was this all decided upon by you
and Kissinger in one evening.
A. Yes.
Q. What time did you see Dr. Reed next morning.

A. It was between 8 and 9 o'clock because I had to be in General Lee's office
by 9 o'clock and it had to be before that when we went to call on Major
Reed
Q. Where did you find Major Reed.
A. He was in his room in the officers' quarters.
Q. Is it your distinct recollection that you and Kissinger went together.
A. Positively. There is no mistake about that.
Q. Do you recollect what you told Major Reed.

A. I do but I cannot tell you my exact words. In substance, the following
happened: We knocked at his door and he received us. He seemed surprised
as he had no idea why we were there and we knew him but slightly up to
that time. Then we informed him, or rather I informed him what Dr. Ames
had told me. I said: Dr. Ames has told me that you are looking for
volunteers and we are here to offer ourselves". Those may not be the
exact words I used, since I was somewhat excited, but according to my
memory they are substantially correct.
Q. Did Kissinger do any talking.

A. Kissinger was the first one to say that “we are doing this without any
thought of compensation or bonus”. I did not repeat this as it was under-
stood between us and by Major Reed. We were all standing, Kissinger at
“attention” because he was a soldier. I was standing “at ease” because
I was a civilian. Major Reed was standing up during the entire conver-
sation and when Kissinger and I told him we were volunteering for the
tests he was taken aback, not so much by our offer, which was surprising
to him, the biggest surprise of all being that we wanted to take the
experiments without reward or compensation.
Q. What did Major Reed do or say.

A. He did not do or say very much. He thanked us and expressed appreciation
for what we were doing but I do not remember his exact words. Recovering
from his surprise, he said: “Of course you know, gentlemen, that this is
a serious matter; that you must first undergo a strict physical examination
to find out whether you have any organic or other trouble before I accept
you as volunteers as I am not looking for any fatalities in these experi-
ments.” After that, his next remarks were: “Now, should you be taken down
with yellow fever, I want you to know that if there is any doctor or nurse
on the Island of Cuba that you care to have to attend you, all you have to
do is name them and I will have General Wood see that they are ordered
here.” That is about he said, adding that we would have our physical
examination in due time.

Q. Did Major Reed at any time rise and salute you and say: “Gentlemen, I
salute you”.

A. No, he did not. He was standing all the time. The conversation lasted
about fifteen minutes.
Q. Where did that legend come from.

A. The first I knew of it was when I read it in Dr. Howard A. Kelly's book
“Walter Reed & Yellow Fever”, first published in 1906.
Q. Do you know where Dr. Kelly got the legend.

A. No, but I discovered later from General Kean, after I informed him of its
inaccuracy, that Major Reed had fathered the legend, adding that “If Major
Reed did not salute you, as alleged, he should have done so.” but whether
the salute was an afterthought, later reported to Dr. Kelly by Major Reed,
I do not know.
Q. When did you hear from Reed or what happened thereafter.

A. About the 1st of November, I think it was, Major Reed told me: You are
through at Headquarters. From now on you are with me until after you are
through with the experiments"
Q. What did you do then.

A. I started in to do clerical work for Major Reed at Columbia Barracks. It
was pretty much pretense on his part since my real work with him was to
undergo the tests. Aside from a few personal letters a day and a few
official ones, all dealing with the experiments, I was not busy over an
average of a few hours a day. I had a “Hammond” typewriter upon which to
type his letters and other notes.

Q. What was the reaction of your friends when they heard that you and Kissinger
-- 3 --
had volunteered.

A. I cannot tell you. All I knew was that volunteers presented themselves
right and left. You have their names. First among them were Dr. Cook,
Jernegan and Folk, who volunteered within a week or ten days after Kiss-
inger and I did. (Ask Kissinger about this reaction).
Q. Did you have any reaction when you were notified to report at Camp Lazear.
A. Not that I can recall.
Q. How were you taken to Camp Lazear.

A. We went in a “Doherty Wagon” (So known in the Army in the days of mule-
drawn transportation)
Q. When did you arrive at the Camp.
A. On November 20th.
Q. When did you arrive at the Camp.
A. On November 20th.
Q. What did you do between November 20th and 26th or before you were bitten.

A. Clerical work for Major Reed, principally typing letters and Notes about
the yellow fever experiments, written in long hand. I occupied the office
tent alone. I had an Army Field Desk in there and a Hammond typewriter.
Major Reed used the field desk when he came to the Camp.
Q. Were the tents numbered.

A. To my knowledge they were not numbered nor were they understood as being
numbered.
Q. You were not the roommate of Kissinger in Tent No. 2?
A. No.
Q. Major Reed did not live in the Camp?

A. No, he stayed at the officers' quarters, within the Post Hospital grounds,
at Columbia Barracks.
Q. Where are Reed's letters to General Sternberg.

A. Those of a personal nature should be in the possession of the General's
family but those of a purely official nature should be in the files of
The Surgeon General of the Army, in Washington.
Q. How long ahead of time did you know you were going to be bitten.

A. About ten minutes ahead of time. The mosquitoes were brought out by
Doctor Reed from the Laboratory of the Post Hospital, one end of which
had been assigned to his use.
Q. Where were you bitten.
A. Outside my tent, on the forearm.
Q. Who put them on you.
A. Major Reed himself put them on my forearm, if I am not mistaken.
Q. What were your reactions.

A. I do not think I had any reactions. If I did, they made no lasting
impression on me.

Q. How long ahead of time did you know you were going into the infected
mosquito building.
A. I think I knew it a day ahead, around December 20th.
Q. How long did it take to complete that building.

A. It was built after the “Infected Bedding & Clothing Building”. I was
getting impatient at the long wait. Dr. Reed tried to pacify me while
the “Mosquito Building” was being put up. He gave me the excuse that
there was not sufficient mosquitoes to put in there. I think it was
ready approximately two weeks before I entered it.
Q. What time were you bitten.
A. Around the noon hour. I do not think anyone took official time there.

Q. Did only one set of men sleep on the other side of the partition in the
“mosquito room”.

A. Only one set of men slept there prior to my entry or first visit. I was
the first to enter the “mosquito room” of the “Mosquito Building”.
Q. Did the men on the other side of the partition only sleep there at night.
A. Yes. During the day, they had the run of the Camp.

Q. Why did Jernegan make the bet. Was he so sure you were going to get
yellow fever.

A. I think it was a gambler's impulse on Jernegan's part. He made the offer
and I took him up.

Q. The official record says you were dizzy at 6 o'clock Christmas morning,
but you tell me that you ate a hearty breakfast?

A. I regret the necessity of contradicting the official record. I did eat a
hearty breakfast, my temperature being normal or slightly subnormal at
6 o'clock Christmas morning.

Q. You did not have any fever on the 23rd or 24th as the official chart
shows.?

A. I am positive I did not. I took my own pulse and temperature regularly
from December 21st to December 25th and had no fever until about 10
o'clock Christmas morning.
Q. You were not put to bed about eleven as the record shows?

A. No. I had Christmas dinner, turkey with cranberry sauce, “Plum Duff”
(plum pudding), eating very sparingly.
Q. Had anyone seen you that morning?

A. No. Major Reed regularly got out to Camp shortly after the noon hour, if he
had not been out in the morning, but it being Christmas Day the officers
at the Post Hospital had their own Christmas Dinner and it was 3 o'clock
when he reached there.
Q. What were your immediate thoughts when you knew you had yellow fever.

A. The same gambling instinct or impulse that caused Jernegan to make the
bet impelled me to accept it and for the time being I was more concerned
with winning the bet than I was about the fever. I wanted to win the
$5.00 as a matter of principle. I am afraid I cannot describe my
thoughts. I knew for one thing that eating heartily with fever, especial-
ly yellow fever, would lessen my chances of pulling through. I ate very
sparingly, bluffing it through without attracting attention.
Q. Christmas afternoon, you were taken where?

A. Into the special tent hospital that was set up to take care of the ex-
perimental cases. It was within the Post Hospital enclosure but a
respectable distance from the wards and barracks which were frame build-
ings. It was known as the Yellow Fever Tent Hospital.
Q. Who visited you there.

A. Major Reed was my constant visitor. Gorgas was a daily visitor, Finlay
only once to my knowledge, and a number of others, including Doctors
Guiteras and Albertini, all members of the Yellow Fever Board of the City
of Havana, not to be confounded with the Yellow Fever Commission or Board
Q. Do you remember any of the conversations these doctors had about you.

A. I do remember that they referred to my case as “a very pretty case”.
Reed, on the secon day, December 26th, when I still had a high temper-
ature, sat down by my bedside and said: “Have you any pains?” I replied:
“Major, I have a lot of pains”. He said: “Please tell me where they are.
Can you localize them?” I replied: “I am sorry but I cannot localize
them as my entire body is a mass of pain. I cannot tell you where. “Are
you suffering?” he asked and I replied that I was. “If yelling out loud
would relieve, then go ahead and do it,” he said. “Major, when I went in
for these experiments I made up my mind to take it without crying about
it,” I said. He said: “All right”.
Q. Do you remember any other conversations.

A. No. Most of their conversations were in an undertone and in medical
terms.
Q. Who had charge of you.
A. Dr. Roger Post Ames was my attending physician.
Q. What were your thoughts? Did you think you were going to die?

A. For the first 48 hours I did not much care whether school kept or not. After
that I figured I would get well.
Q. What were your symptoms besides pains and fever.
A. None.
Q. How long were you sick.

A. I was out of bed in ten days. When declared convalescent, I was still very
weak as I had no nourishment for a period of seven days running.
Q. You took the blood test about two weeks after your convalescence?
A. About January 15th, 1901.

Q. Do you remember any instance of local reaction that you came across before
you left Havana?
A. No.
Q. Why did you leave Havana in February, 1901?

A. I returned to the U. S. and had a position assured me in Luerssen's Drug
Store, Salem, N. J. which, due to its nature, suited me until I should matri-
culate as a medical student in September of the same year.

Q. Did you have any other conversations with Reed or Carroll about your own or
other experiments?
A. None in particular that I can recall.
Q. Did you only meet Finlay once?

A. To my knowledge only once and I do not remember having any conversations with
him. Dr. Finlay could have seen me on December 26th without my being aware of
it. On that date, I was not a close observer.
Q. Do you remember any errors in Dr. Kelly's book except those we have discussed.
A. I do not recall any.
Q. You said there were errors in the Furnas article “Death in a Mirror”?

A. Yes, but not serious ones. Where he identifies Dr. Ames as a Virginia grad-
uate, he is in error. Dr. Ames was a graduate of Tulane, I am reasonably sure.
As I explained to Mr. Furnas, the man who suggested Virginia to me first was
Major Alexander N. Stark, Post Surgeon, under whom I worked in the operating
room until my term of enlistment expired on July 2, 1900. After I volunteered
for the experiments, I discovered that Major Reed was a Virginia graduate and
that my very good friend and benefactor, Major Jefferson R. Kean, Chief Surg-
eon of the Department, was also a Virginia graduate. At the time I volunteered
all three knew that I was to enter Virginia in September of the coming year.
Q. The statement about the poker is true?

A. Yes. There were other little games too where a few dollars could be won or
lost. Prisoners, as we were, indulgence in these pastimes helped shorten the
day for us.
Q. The Conversation between you and Reed?

A. Essentially correct. The first time I ever heard the expression “fool-proof”
was when Major Reed used it when he informed me that he was “saving” me for
his “mosquito building” test. His elation on Christmas Day, when he found me
with yellow fever, is much better told by Joe Furnas than I could ever hope
to tell it.
Q. What about the muslin-lined walls in the mosquito room?

A. That is more or less correct. There were screened windows on which very fine
copper bronze wire screening was used. The room was built from tongue and
grooved lumber. After that, the ceiling and walls were “papered” with unbleach-
ed muslin, making them insect proof.
Q. Did you ever have Malaria?

A. Yes, I had it for the first time at Camp Young, near Guanajay, Province of
Pinar del Rio.

Q. What were your duties after you enlisted in the Army and immediately before
your enlistment expired?

A. I enlisted as a Private at the Hospital School of Instruction, Washington
Barracks, D. C., was promoted to Acting Hospital Steward (Sergeant) about a
year later. From date of my promotion my duties were varied. At times I
had charge of the pharmacy, accompany the surgeon in his daily visits to the
wards, prepare “Sick & Wounded” reports and do other clerical work. My last
six or seven months of Army service were as assistant to Major Stark, in the
operating room. While in Cuba, I served, respectively, at Camp Young, Guan-
ajay Barracks and Columbia Barracks.
Q. How long were you in service in Cuba?

A. As a soldier, from January, 1899, until July 2, 1900. As a civilian or field
clerk, from July 2, 1900, to February, 1901.
Q. Why did not Major Reed try the experiments on himself?

A. I think he was too old, which was of itself sufficient reason. He was then
in his 50th year.

Q. The official record says Carroll's yellow fever was experimental. What was
the opinion in and around the Post Hospital as to this?

A. That Doctor Carroll's case was accidental - not experimental. His friend and
preceptor, Major Reed, was willing to pass his yellow fever as experimental
and allowed it to so appear in the record. When I knew Dr. Carroll he was
far from robust and he was in his 46th year. Although Major Reed was three
years his senior, his chances of surviving an attack of yellow fever were
much greater than Carroll's. The latter, I inferred at the time, was organically
unsound. One of my doctor friends, whose name I do not care to disclose, con-
firmed to me what was general opinion among the Post Hospital personnel.

Q. Agramonte says that at first Lazear kept the mosquitoes not at Camp Columbia
but in Agramonte's laboratory at Military Hospital No. 1. Is this correct?

A. I cannot give you a positive answer. According to my recollection, they were
kept in the old operating room (then used as a laboratory) under the personal
supervision of Hospital Steward Neal who accompanied Major Reed and Dr.
Carroll to Cuba from the Army Medical School in Washington.

Q. Is the conversation you are supposed to have had with Kissinger, as given by
Lampson on page 472 of his book, essentially correct.?

A. It is incorrect in every respect; entirely imaginary. Lampson is probably not
responsible. I think he got his impression from the theatre version of the
play “Yellow Jack”.
Q. On page 474?

A. You are entirely familiar with Major Reed's remarks when, on Christmas Day,
1900, he found me with yellow fever, hence I will not here repeat them.

div1.p:
The FOURTH question, counting either from the top or bottom of this page,
is mine. You are entirely free to eliminate it. It may be policy to do so.
In this revised copy of your questionnaire, I have corrected a number of errors
made by Mrs. Phillips, excusable always even on the part of competent steno-
graphers when typing from shorthand notes. Instance: She used FLAT DESK where
I said “Field Desk”, the latter being a portable or folding desk, used at that
time by officers in the field.
